column5: as many sectors and services were either impaired or fully shut down over the period of Covid. We are now seeing the outcome of all of that play out. There is also a range of international factors. We are all witnessing the increases in electricity prices and in fuel costs generally. We acknowledge as a Government that this places an obligation on us to take account of that and to respond in the context of the budget
column6: and that is what we will do. We also acknowledge the comments made by the European Central Bank and its monitoring of inflation across the eurozone. In broad terms
column7: it is fair to say that it believes the current trend is a temporary one. The European Central Bank is monitoring very closely what it regards as the underlying inflation trend across the eurozone because
column8: of course
column9: we have benefited very significantly from the bond purchase programme. The exceptional interventions of the European Central Bank in the markets have helped to keep borrowing costs low for Ireland over the past 18 months or so. Undoubtedly
column10: that is what has helped us to fund the additional spending on services and on income support for households
column11: businesses
column12: etc. We equally acknowledge that this will not continue forever. The European Central Bank will keep a very close eye on inflationary pressures across the eurozone and will stand ready over the course of next year to adjust its policies accordingly. From our perspective
column13: we see recovery taking hold in Ireland over the period ahead through a number of means. We will have a really ambitious public capital investment programme and will be spending approximately €11 billion next year on that capital programme
column17: in transport and in climate action measures to name but a few. We will spend up to €50 billion of direct Exchequer capital over the next four years
column20: risk in the way in which we will taper off and gradually unwind the Covid supports. There may well be businesses that are surviving by virtue of those supports. The removal of those supports over time may well raise fundamental questions for some of those businesses but that day will have to be faced at some point in time because these supports cannot continue indefinitely. Overall
column21: we recognise that there is a strong rebound under way. We anticipate that this will transition to a strong recovery. The fiscal advisory council has
column23: endorsed the latest economic forecasts that have been made by the Department of Finance and those will be published imminently. There are strong grounds for optimism that both in terms of foreign direct investment and in the domestic economy
column24: the recovery is sustainable. We face challenges for sure
column25: but the Government is determined to work its way through them and to help the recovery through its investment and through its supports and by not prematurely or abruptly ending the supports that are such a vital lifeline for so many businesses around the country.

column1: #MichaelMcGrath	unknown-#MichaelMcGrath-party	unknown-#MichaelMcGrath-dob	unknown-#MichaelMcGrath-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2021-09-30 00:00:00	Pre-Budget 2022 Scrutiny (Resumed): Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform	25	I thank the Deputy. That is a really good question. In general terms
column2: the real relevance of the measure of national debt is debt expressed as a percentage of national income. For Ireland
column3: we have two key measures of debt
column4: the first being as a percentage of GDP and the second being as a percentage of GNI*. Of course
column5: the debt looks a lot more healthy as a percentage of GDP than it does as a percentage of GNI*. However
column6: we need to get it on a downward trajectory. We believe that we will do that
column7: primarily through growth in the Irish economy. I refer to all of the international forecasts that we are working to
column8: from the OECD and the European Commission
column9: which are complemented by domestic forecasts.They point to a level of confidence that Ireland as a small open trading economy
column10: which is well positioned to benefit from a recovery in the international economy
column11: will see continued growth over the coming years. It makes it all the more important that in the coming years
column12: we stop adding to the national debt. It will hit €250 billion next year. By 2025 it will hit €280 billion. Coming into Covid it was approximately €200 billion. This will represent an €80 billion increase in the national debt over the course of a five-year period. This is a reality we cannot escape. This is why our plan on the public finances is to close the budget deficit in order that we stop adding to the national debt and then that we grow the economy over the next number of years so the debt relative to the size of the economy shrinks. These are the twin strategies we have to pursue to make sure our debt is sustainable in the medium and long term.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2021-09-30 00:00:00	Pre-Budget 2022 Scrutiny (Resumed): Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform	26	On the reward for essential and front-line workers and for people generally who sacrificed during Covid
column2: I very much welcome this conversation. It has become controversial. It may be somewhat difficult for the Minister but it is very good that we are having a difficult and controversial conversation. Many people went unacknowledged and unrecognised for a long time as to the importance of the work they did to keep our society going. Generally
column3: the right approach in terms of the immediate recompense is the engagement with the various groups that the Minister is now speaking about. Obviously
column4: there are different groups of workers
column5: whether they be front-line health workers
column6: most importantly
column7: but also public transport workers
column8: local authority workers
column9: retail workers and carers. They all had different experiences
column10: played different roles and had different difficulties and challenges. We need to talk to them. I will give an example in which I was particularly involved which demonstrates something about how we need to listen to people on the ground. This is the case of Dublin Bus workers. After all they did for us during Covid
column11: a proposal was put by the NTA and the company that would fundamentally attack their conditions of employment and lead them to work much longer hours. Somebody dreamt up a plan for how to reconfigure Dublin Bus services which in the process would destroy the quality of life of the drivers. They give a resounding "No" to that. This is an example of how we have to listen to workers on the ground to see what their experiences are. Beyond the immediate reward
column12: what many people out there are looking for
column13: whether they were on the front line or just sacrificed terribly because they could not work
column14: is longer-term recognition of their importance
column15: which has sometimes been undervalued. The arts and music sector is an obvious area. There are many others. In many cases our supermarket workers are chronically low paid. They suffer precarity and the issue of low pay more generally. I would be interested to see whether these types of recognition are part of the longer-term lessons we learned
column16: as well as the short term. I would add to the Minister's consideration that some people who were under-recognised did a huge amount for us and sacrificed a lot for us and lost out in one shape or form during the pandemic. Others did very well. Some sectors of our economy saw profits go through the roof. I wonder in the context of the budget should there not be serious consideration given
column18: to a Covid solidarity tax on those who did very well. I ask the Minister to comment on this. On the health service
column19: perhaps the Minister could be a bit more specific about the lessons he has learned on the increased areas of expenditure he is considering. We know our ICU levels were some of the worst as a proportion of population in Europe entering Covid. Will we rectify this and get to the previously recommended levels? At least we should get up to the EU average. So we do not just respond in an emergency way and are desperately clambering
column20: will we get our public health teams up to the levels they should be at so there are permanent increases in capacity? All of these were recommended pre-Covid but in some cases we learned to our cost what the cost can be if we do not have the capacity when we hit an emergency. Perhaps the Minister will say a little bit more about what the permanent areas of increased expenditure to deliver increased capacity in health will be. I ask the Minister to clarify some matters on housing. The figure of €4 billion per annum over the course of Housing for All is being bandied around. Is this direct Exchequer funding? Can we have a little bit more detail on what this €4 billion is and where it is coming from? Is it €4 billion additional or is it €4 billion in total to the Department? What I want to know is how much of it is directly going into the direct construction by local authorities and approved housing bodies of new public and affordable housing. How much of it will continue in the rental accommodation scheme
column22: leasing or other expenditure that is not about directly delivering housing? Perhaps the Minister will say a few words about that. A lot of borrowing is being done. It was justified to borrow to meet the challenges we faced. There is a danger in borrowing because it has to be paid back. We have always argued
column24: that we should think more about taxing increased contributions in the area of profits
column25: financial transactions and employers' PRSI in order that we increase our revenue but not at the expense of ordinary working people who suffered so much during this period. Has the Minister drawn conclusions about needing to rebalance our tax system in this way
column27: the very wealthy and financial services pay a bigger contribution in tax rather than having to rely on very high levels of borrowing?

column1: #MichaelMcGrath	unknown-#MichaelMcGrath-party	unknown-#MichaelMcGrath-dob	unknown-#MichaelMcGrath-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2021-09-30 00:00:00	Pre-Budget 2022 Scrutiny (Resumed): Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform	27	I thank Deputy Boyd Barrett. There is much to cover there and I will be as brief as I can but as helpful as I possibly can. The Deputy is right to point out that in coming to an appropriate answer on the question of recognition it is not about the Government having a conversation with itself. We do not have all the wisdom on this issue. Our country's approach to Covid was characterised by a collective effort and incredible solidarity by and large throughout the country. This is a complex and difficult issue. We recognise there is a need for special recognition to be given for the efforts of so many people. No one could dispute that front-line healthcare workers are at the very top of that tree in terms of the exposure and work they did. Others did an awful lot too and went above and beyond. It is challenging and complex. We need to come up with an answer and we will do this in a collaborative way. We have a Labour Employer Economic Forum
column2: LEEF
column3: process. It is a very suitable forum for us to discuss the issue in an open and honest way with trade union representatives and employer bodies. The Deputy touched on carers. This is the point I made last week. Many carers had to carry an enormous burden over the course of the pandemic when disability services stopped and were shut down overnight on public health grounds. Carers had to provide 24-7 care. Many of them will point out they do this in normal times anyway but a far greater number of them had to carry this. How do we compensate and acknowledge their efforts?It is impossible. We cannot put a value on it
column4: and that is the truth. The long-term legacy is better public services generally
column5: and that is certainly something I and my party strongly believe in. On the issue of working conditions and the issue of having a genuine appreciation for the role of people in society on whom we really rely
column6: I believe we understood that in a very clear way over the course of the 18 months. The Deputy mentioned a number of those sectors. That whole agenda is one the Government is committed to
column7: and we will make progress in regard to low pay
column8: working conditions generally and providing as much support and opportunity as possible for people. In regard to health
column9: the additional spending
column10: both last year and into the future
column11: is first and foremost to build up the permanent capacity of the public health service. Last year
column13: the funding we provided was sufficient to increase the number of acute beds in our hospital system by more than 1
column15: which was a very significant step. It will not be fully met in delivery but it will be largely met
column16: and the outturn will go a long way towards that. The funding that was provided for that last year will be considered as part of the Estimates process. If they were not able to spend it this year
column17: the intention would be to allow them to keep that funding so they can implement fully next year those reforms we would have discussed and agreed last year. Beds is one issue and the Deputy mentioned critical care capacity. That has to be a learning from Covid
column18: if we are to be honest with ourselves. We did withstand the Covid challenge and the Covid surge
column19: but at a price. No country can take the risk of its public health service being overwhelmed because of capacity issues. The Government is committed to dealing with the capacity issue in acute bed care and critical care capacity over the period ahead. I think we have made very good progress
column20: even in the midst of a global pandemic. In regard to housing
column21: the specific allocation from the Exchequer to the Department of Housing
column22: Local Government and Heritage will be confirmed on Monday when we publish the new national development plan out to 2030. It is important to acknowledge that housing will be getting very significant increases
column23: which will underpin the delivery of the Housing for All programme. The figure the Deputy mentioned of €4 billion does involve some non-direct Exchequer funding
column26: but it is public in the broad sense of the word
column27: and it is going towards building homes - social homes
column28: affordable homes and cost rental homes. I think it is fair to put that figure in the total public investment by the State in meeting the challenge of Housing for All. The direct Exchequer element of that public contribution will be set out when we publish the national development plan on Monday. It will represent a very large increase in capital spending for the Department of Housing
column29: Local Government and Heritage over the next number of years.

column18: it is going to be wrong

column36: I should not be meeting with this person." It is the exact opposite. I think every person in the Dáil should be meeting with developers

#MichaelMcGrath	unknown-#MichaelMcGrath-party	unknown-#MichaelMcGrath-dob	unknown-#MichaelMcGrath-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2021-09-30 00:00:00	Pre-Budget 2022 Scrutiny (Resumed): Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform	32	I will
column2: briefly. It will be difficult to respond because that was a comprehensive tour de force by the Deputy
column3: although I thank him for his comments. I acknowledge what he said about the recognition issue. We will seek to deal with that as quickly as possible but I do not envisage it will be a budget day issue. We need proper engagement with trade unions and employer bodies to come up with a considered response to this issue. Otherwise
column4: we run the risk of significant divisions in society on the back of it. I look at the email traffic coming into my consistency office
column5: as I am sure the Deputy too does every day
column6: and many people are expressing a view on this issue. It is fair to say there is not a consensus but rather a wide set of views on the matter. That is not a reason to address it
column7: which we will do

column9: I know those demands can only be met
column10: in part

column12: enterprise-based economy. That is what gives us the funding to have good public services and a decent society underpinned by those services. I understand that and it is why I have no hesitation in engaging directly with employers

column18: which meets regularly and involves officials in my Department and also those representing the industry and the professions. It is about listening to them and coming up with solutions. I have never built a house

column21: the private sector. There is much talk about building houses but very little talk about putting in place the water
column22: the wastewater infrastructure and the other services needed to build homes. That is an important aspect. The Deputy raised a fundamental question about getting more people with direct private sector experience into politics. There are some but more are needed
column23: as is more mobility into and out of politics. We need people to come into politics with life experience and a full career behind them of getting things done in the private sector and who are willing to offer themselves in the interests of public service. I want to see more of that rather than less
column24: and that is a challenge for all of us. Perhaps it is about the way we do politics and the challenges involved in being in public life now that some people simply would not tolerate.

column9: what they really want is a commitment to multi-annual increases in funding. We set out the overall framework in the summer economic statement. Built into that is an increase in core current expenditure of close to 4.75%. As such
column10: there can be a legitimate expectation that there will be increases in expenditure generally
column11: but it has to fall to the Government
column13: to set its priorities and monitor progress on the implementation of the programme for Government. A degree of flexibility is needed because some Departments and projects may be ahead of schedule
column14: while others may get stuck in the system. One needs an ability to make budget day decisions. I am not completely averse to multi-annual and there are certain specific areas where it would be helpful. Several Ministers have raised that directly with me and we are examining it.
